events.name: Android meetup - Kotlin & libraries
events.description:
Let's meet at Wix office to learn from Android developers from two great companies: Trafi and Wix.

• 18:30 Doors open (there will be snacks and drinks sponsored by Wix)
• 19:00 Justas Medeišis will talk about Developer happiness with Kotlin @ Trafi
• 20:00 Yoni Gross - Developing Android SDKs and libraries

Yoni Gross' Bio:

Software Engineer at Wix mobile team. Developing software for more than 10 years, last 6 of them are focused on mobile. Built and maintained various libraries - from open source libraries, through a dedicated plugins for 3rd parties, to SDKs installed on millions of devices.

Developing Android SDKs and libraries:

Building libraries or SDKs is somewhat different from building apps - your users may not only use your product wrong (and ask you for support), but they’ll also discover bugs, abuse it, and fork it or reverse-engineer. However, it’s your job to make their life as easy as possible while protecting them from theirselves, your library from them, and most important - their apps from your library.

We’ll talk about best practices, tooling, philosophy, and common pitfalls of every stage in Android library development - from general API design to packaging and distribution, covering many areas such as security, performance, resource management, build scripts, and other various Android consideration

events.name: Kotlin.Native: cross platform Android/iOS development
events.description:
TL;DR
Doors: 18:30
Talks: 19:00
Presenter: Alexander Podkhalyuzin from JetBrains
Presentation language: LT
Networking till: 21:00

Main talk:
Kotlin is going to be the standard language for Android. We already see lots of teams moving to this very promising language. But in JetBrains we just don't want to stop on that. So we are working on Kotlin.Native, the same language, different backend. And one of the most promising applications for this backend is iOS development.

In this talk I'll do short introduction into Kotlin language itself with description of some high level design ideas. Next step will be discussions around Native as a platform. I'll show you current complications with it and possible solutions. And finally we will go to iOS. You will see cross compiled Android/iOS example as well as example with just shared business logic. As a bonus I'll show you infinite possibilities about single language with all the parts, backend, frontend and two mobile apps.

Bio:
My name is Alexander Podkhalyuzin. I work for JetBrains from 2008 and 9 years I spent working on Scala plugin for IntelliJ IDEA. Last year I decided to go further and switched to Kotlin team, I started working on Kotlin.Native support in CLion and finished leading Kotlin tooling team, which includes general Kotlin support in IntelliJ IDEA and other IDEs.
Before JetBrains I studied math quite successfully. That was one of my touches with Vilnius as I participated in Baltic Way math competition, where our team from St. Petersburg won. And that's not the all about my connection to the Lithuania as my mother born in Lithuania and Lithuanian is my second mother tongue language. So I'll try to do this talk in Lithuanian, the first time in my life, I hope it will be fun, so see you in Vilnius!

Warm-up talk:
Cross-Platform Knowledge
Eligijus Starinskas (Trafi), Justas Medeišis (Trafi)

At a lean startup with separate native Android and iOS apps and only a handful of mobile developers, we have explored both technical and human approaches to minimize duplicate work - thin clients, a shared C++ library, cross-functional teams. This experience has led us to a new standard for collaboration across Android and iOS developers inspired by domain-driven design. By working closely we 'steal' code from the other platform and do most of the work once without sacrificing the native language and development toolkit of each platform.

This talk explores the challenges and benefits of collaborating closely across Android and iOS.
- Common constraints on both mobile platforms, and what Android developers can learn from iOS community solutions.
- Core similarities and differences between Kotlin and Swift, and how the languages help bridge communication across the two platforms.
- Work practices and code principles that reduce the friction of cross-platform knowledge sharing.

events.name: Google Developers Community Roadshow in Vilnius
events.description:
Join Google Developers Community Roadshow in Vilnius!

Main information at https://events.withgoogle.com/community-roadshow-2018
Please register yourself main website: https://events.withgoogle.com/community-roadshow-2018/registrations/

This summer, Google Developers team is touring ten countries and fourteen cities in Europe in a colourful community bus. We'll meet you locally and talk about our programs for developers and start-ups.
Come and find out how Google supports developer communities, see the exhibition in our colorful community bus, and relax in the chillout zone.

What to expect:

- Information: learn more about how Google supports developer communities around the world, from content, speakers to a global network
- Network: with other community organizers from your city
- Workshops: join some of our product workshops on tour (Actions on Google, Google Cloud, Machine Learning), and meet with Google teams
- Fun: live music, games and more!

Where:

Central Park area at Vilnius Tech Park (Antakalnio St. 17) https://goo.gl/maps/1HR2bUWHRe52

Agenda:

12.00 (noon)
Roadshow opening

[masked]
Tech talks & chillout zone
12.10 - 12.40 Communities program presentation
12.40 - 13.00 Music / DJ
13.00 - 13.15 Kahoot - quiz about the community with prizes
13.15 - 13.30 Music / DJ
13.30 - 13.45 Google Cloud Community groups presentation
13.45 - 14.00 Music / DJ
14.00 - 14.15 Kahoot - quiz about the community with prizes
14.15 - 14.30 Local GDG group presentation
14.30 - 14.45 WTM program presentation
14.45 - 15.00 Kahoot - quiz about the community with prizes
15.00 - 15.15 Music / DJ
15.15 - 15.45 Google engineers tech talk

[masked]
Introduction to Machine Learning with Tensorflow

Workshop led by Oleksandr Zakharchuk, Google Developers Expert
To attend the workshop, register at https://bit.ly/2IR69JY

This session is a quick tour of the machine learning basics. We will try our hand at classifying images from Fashion MNIST dataset using TensorFlow. The tasks will be performed in Collaboratory (colab.research.google.com). The only prerequisite for this session is the ability to write and understand Python code. Please don’t forget to bring your laptop!

[masked]
Practical ML with Tensorflow
Where: Central park area at Vilnius Tech Park

Workshop led by Oleksandr Zakharchuk, Google Developers Expert
To attend the workshop, register at https://bit.ly/2IR69JY

In this session, we’ll cover some of the practical aspects of using ML in startups. The topics will include using pre-trained models and transfer learning. You must know the basic ML concepts in order to benefit from this workshop. We advise you to go through the online Machine Crash Course if you have no prior experience with machine learning. The tasks will be performed in Collaboratory (colab.research.google.com). Please don’t forget to bring your laptop!

4.00 pm
Roadshow closing

events.name: GDG Vilnius: Firebase
events.description:
The theme for the meetup: Firebase. Firebase offers a range of products for rapid mobile development.

This event requires registration on Eventbrite: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gdg-vilnius-firebase-meetup-tickets-51583501642

Agenda
19:00 - “Machine learning for mobile developers using Firebase” by Jumana Al Hashal
19:50 - "Focus on the User and all else will follow” by Benjamin Ferrari-Church
20:30 - Q&A

“Machine learning for mobile developers using Firebase”

This talk will cover new machine learning capabilities available for mobile app and game developers inside Firebase.

Jumana is a product manager at Google. She leads Firebase Predictions, a machine-learning service providing smart user segmentation for mobile games and apps. Before joining Google, she led mobile products at Zillow. Jumana loves helping developers grow their apps and build delightful experiences for their users. She enjoys games (making them and playing them), scuba diving, and prickly machine learning problems. Jumana holds a master's degree from the University of Washington.
Twitter: http://twitter.com/objectivejay
Linkedin: http://linkedin.com/in/objectivejay

"Focus on the User and all else will follow"

This talk will give an overview of user research concepts and a quick how-to guide for doing your own usability research.

Ben is a UX researcher by day and restauranteur by night. As a Googler, he works to be the voice of developers in product decisions for Firebase, which is Google's mobile development platform.
Before joining Firebase he worked at a number of startups in the San Francisco Bay Area.

Location: Rise Vilnius, 14 Gynėjų gatvė, 01109 Vilnius

events.name: GDG Vilnius: Firebase & DevFest Baltics
events.description:
The theme for the meetup: Firebase & DevFest Baltics 2018

Agenda
18:30 - Doors open
19:00 - "Jump start into Firebase" by Yohan Wadia
19:50 - "Firebase Predictions" lightning talk by Justas Medeišis
20:00 - "DevFest Baltics 2018” lightning review by Martynas Bardauskas
20:10 - Wrap up & beers at a nearby bar, if anyone's interested

Yohan Wadia have been predominantly in 2 industries, IT and Advertising. Over the last 20 years he has worked with numerous technologies & languages. Covered software requirements for numerous industries: Accounting, ERP, Insurance, Bidding, Education, Health, Finger Print Reco etc... But in the last 4 years with Firebase, have seen the biggest breakthroughs. In his spare time, as a hobbyist, he loves developing android games from scratch!

Justas Medeišis is a mobile engineer and team lead at Trafi, working to make private transport obsolete.

Martynas Bardauskas is a JavaScript developer and Guild Master at Wix.com, currently building Wix mobile presence with React Native.

Location: Wix.com, Didžioji g. 28 (3rd floor)

events.name: GDG Vilnius: ARCore
events.description:
The theme for the meetup: Augmented Reality. ARCore is Google’s platform for building augmented reality experiences.

Location: Technopolis Delta Vilnius (J. Balčikonio g. 9, Vilnius)

Agenda
18:30 - Doors open
19:00 - "Augmented Reality – current state and possibilities" by Žilvinas Ledas & Šarūnas Ledas
19:45 - "AR enhanced by ML" by Gintaras Jakimavičius
20:30- Q&A

As a team, we were experimenting with Augmented Reality (AR) from 2011. We implemented multiple marketing experiences that used AR, but our biggest project to date utilising AR is "Monster Buster: World Invasion" game: http://www.tagofjoy.lt/?dna=11 . Back when we started, possibilities were limited, but now multiple frameworks and platforms exist. As a result, implementing AR is not so time consuming.
In this talk we'll introduce AR basics, use cases and investigate possibilities across platforms. We are not planning a long presentation (10-15 minutes), but we'll leave a lot of time for your questions and discussion!

Žilvinas Ledas is PhD of informatics and develops video games more than 7 years now. Currently Žilvinas is a co-founder and CTO at Tag of Joy - an indie game development company which creates innovative games merging fun and innovation. With their products the team has gained multiple awards at various international competitions. He also teaches Game Development at Vilnius University and is active in local game development community.
Šarūnas has been involved in game development for 15 years and is currently a co-founder and CEO of an award-winning indie game development studio Tag of Joy. The company constantly looks for new ways to innovate experiences in games, and has already won multiple awards and nominations. Šarūnas is also the chairman of the board at the Lithuanian Game Developers Association, which helps local game developers meet, share their knowledge and learn.

Gintaras Jakimavičius- Passionate games and experienced mobile apps developer. He has been developing for mobile platforms for more than 8 years (iOS, Android, Unity). Mobile development is such a new area that being an early adopter is a must. Last couple of years working as a freelancer allowed to stay on the top of innovation chain (cross-platform with ReactNative, ML, AR). Gintaras will share about AR from a different side - as most experience comes from iOS platform and applying ML on mobile.

events.name: GDG Vilnius: Virtual Art Gallery: building AR on the web!
events.description:
Agenda
18:30 - Doors open
19:00 - "Virtual Art Gallery: building AR on the web!" by Doug Sillars
19:30- Q&A

The world of virtual reality allows us to build new 3D interactive spaces that we can fill with anything we want - like the art of the great Renaissance masters. More into Cubism? With a quick click - now the gallery is full of a completely different genre. With new AR features, we can actually build the gallery in our own space - and just as easily swap out the art - all in our browser!

In this talk, we’ll walk through the steps to build a virtual ARt gallery, with web technology available today, but also take a peek at the new WebXR technology that is coming to our browsers soon!

Doug Sillars is a Web Google Developer Expert, author of O’Reilly’s “High Performance Android Apps” and focuses on improving the performance of websites.

Let's meet at Trafi office to learn about possibilities to build an Art Gallery in the Browser with web technologies.

group_profile.intro: Android developer, VR & IoT enthusiast, early adopter - I like trying new stuff.
